header.title: Donald Trump SNUB: US President unlikely to address Parliament during UK state visit
header.subtitle: DONALD TRUMP is unlikely to address Parliament during his UK state visit next month due to fears House Speaker John Bercow would refuse the request - which could embarrass the Queen.
header.postText: The US President will visit the UK from June 3-6, to coincide with D-day commemorations. However, Mr Trump is unlikely to address Parliament, due to the Speaker’s outspoken opposition to the President. Mr Bercow has already snubbed the Queen’s invitation to attend a banquet held for Mr Trump and in 2017, after the offer of a state visit was first made by Theresa May, the Speaker said he would oppose the President addressing Parliament.', 'Mr Trump’s full itinerary for the state visit is yet to be discussed by UK and US officials, but once agreed usual protocol dictates that Buckingham Palace should then request invitations for the US President to address both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.', 'But Government sources suggest that a request is unlikely to be made as it is anticipated that Mr Bercow would not grant the invitation, which could potentially embarrass the Queen, The Guardian reports.', 'Addresses have been made by Mr Trump’s predecessors, including Barack Obama, Bill Clinton and Ronald Reagan.', 'In 2017, Mr Bercow told MP’s that addressing Parliament was “an earned honour” and explained that his opposition had been prompted by the Trump-proposed ban on visitors from Muslim countries.', 'He said: “I feel very strongly that our opposition to racism and sexism and our support for equality before the law and an independent judiciary are hugely important considerations in the House of Commons.”', 'But Lord Fowler, the Lord Speaker opposed Mr Bercow’s stance.', 'He said it was unacceptable to bar a longstanding UK ally from addressing Parliament.', 'Lord Flower told the Cambridge Union Society: “I profoundly object to any attempt to ban the president when he is coming to Europe to mark the anniversary of the D-day landings when so many Americans were killed and wounded in defence of our freedom.', '“It also seems to me that if our role inside Westminster is to uphold the rights of backbenchers and their right to free speech, it would be ironic to apply a different standard to the elected president of the United States.', '“It is my view that we should not stifle views we may disagree with or shy away from lively debate.”', 'Several leading MP’s have already refused the Queen’s invitation to the state banquet being held for the US President.', 'This includes Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Mr Bercow, Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable and SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford.
